title: Fake Bhutanese Refugee Scam
description:
The Fake Bhutanese Refugee Scam is a high-profile corruption and organized crime case in Nepal involving a network of politicians, government officials, and intermediaries. The syndicate is accused of defrauding hundreds of Nepali citizens by collecting vast sums of money with the false promise of resettling them in the United States and other developed countries as Bhutanese refugees.

The core of the scheme involved manipulating an official government process. A task force, led by former joint-secretary Bal Krishna Panthi, was formed in 2019 to find solutions for the remaining Bhutanese refugees in Nepal. The accused allegedly created a counterfeit version of this task force's confidential report, inserting the names of paying Nepali citizens to present them as refugees eligible for resettlement. Victims paid amounts ranging from NPR 1 million to over NPR 5 million for these forged identities.

The case came to public attention after victims filed complaints. The initial complaint on June 1, 2022, involved 81 victims who claimed to have been cheated of a collective NPR 130 million. Subsequent investigations by Nepal Police led to charges being filed by the Kathmandu District Attorney's Office against 30 individuals. The total fraud amount cited in the charge sheet for 115 victims reached NPR 288.17 million.

The investigation exposed a deep nexus of corruption, leading to the arrests of several high-profile figures, including former Deputy Prime Minister Top Bahadur Rayamajhi and former Home Minister Bal Krishna Khand. The accused face serious charges, including:

  • Treason
  • Organized Crime
  • Fraud
  • Forgery
unverified_info:
The following claims and allegations have been reported in the media but were not part of the initial official charges filed by the District Attorney's Office. They are included here for tracking purposes:

  • An audio recording allegedly surfaced claiming that money was paid to Manju Khand, wife of former Home Minister Bal Krishna Khand.
  • The names of Arzu Rana Deuba, a Nepali Congress leader and wife of former Prime Minister Sher Bahadur Deuba, and the son of former Home Minister Ram Bahadur Thapa were mentioned by some of the accused during the investigation.
  • A defendant's statement reportedly alleged that Ajaya Kranti Shakya, an adviser to former Prime Minister KP Sharma Oli, received NPR 10 million. Shakya was not named as a defendant in the case.
key_allegations: Defrauding hundreds of Nepali citizens with false promises of US resettlement as Bhutanese refugees.
Illegally collecting crores of rupees from victims, with charge sheets mentioning NPR 288.17 million from 115 victims.
Forgery of a confidential government task force report to include names of non-refugees.
Operating as an organized criminal syndicate involving high-level politicians, bureaucrats, and middlemen.
Committing treason by undermining national security and government processes.
alleged_entities: Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of Nepal

timeline.title: Victims File Formal Complaint
timeline.description: A group of 81 victims filed a formal complaint with the police, alleging they were collectively defrauded of NPR 130 million in the fake refugee scheme.

timeline.title: Police Begin Arrests
timeline.description: Police began a series of arrests, starting with key middlemen involved in the scam, including Keshav Dulal, Sanu Bhandari, and Tanka Gurung.

timeline.title: Arrest Warrant for Top Bahadur Rayamajhi
timeline.description: An arrest warrant was issued for CPN-UML Secretary and former Deputy Prime Minister Top Bahadur Rayamajhi, who subsequently went into hiding.

timeline.title: Former Home Minister Bal Krishna Khand Arrested
timeline.description: Former Home Minister and Nepali Congress leader Bal Krishna Khand was arrested from his residence in Mainjubahal, Kathmandu.

timeline.title: Top Bahadur Rayamajhi Arrested
timeline.description: After being on the run for 10 days, former Deputy Prime Minister Top Bahadur Rayamajhi was arrested in Budhanilkantha, Kathmandu.

timeline.title: Case Filed at Kathmandu District Court
timeline.description: The Kathmandu District Attorney's Office filed a case against 30 individuals, charging them with fraud, forgery, organized crime, and treason.

timeline.title: Court Orders Pre-Trial Detention
timeline.description: The Kathmandu District Court ordered 16 of the accused, including Bal Krishna Khand and Top Bahadur Rayamajhi, to be sent to judicial custody for pre-trial detention. Two others were released on bail.

timeline.title: Fugitive Recaptured After Prison Escape
timeline.description: Sandesh Sharma Pokhrel, identified as a key planner in the scam who had escaped from prison, was recaptured by police.

timeline.title: Another Fugitive Middleman Arrested
timeline.description: Niranjan Kumar Kharel, an alleged middleman who had been absconding, was arrested. The Central Investigation Bureau (CIB) subsequently reopened and intensified parts of the investigation.

timeline.title: Patan High Court Orders Khand's Release on Bail
timeline.description: The Patan High Court upheld the decision to keep Top Bahadur Rayamajhi in custody but ordered the release of former Home Minister Bal Krishna Khand on a bail of NPR 3 million.

timeline.title: Supreme Court Rules on Detention
timeline.description: The Supreme Court of Nepal ordered that Top Bahadur Rayamajhi and Indrajit Rai remain in custody during the trial. The same order set bail for Angtawa Sherpa and Govinda Kumar Chaudhary and ordered the release of Shamsher Miya on a general date.

timeline.title: Final Hearing Begins
timeline.description: The final hearing of the fake Bhutanese refugee case began at the Kathmandu District Court.
